questions.text: A young Marathon runner complaining of pain on walking and running in anterior and medial aspect of tibia. The X-rays findings are normal. Further bone scan was advised. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is a case of Medial tibial stress syndrome [MTSS]/ shin splints – periostitis of Tibia, pain starts after 5 minutes of running, subsides after taking rest. X-Rays are normal. Investigation of choice is MRI, TREATMENT: rest, ice packs, immobilization. Nutcracker fracture is an intraarticular fracture of cuboid. Jones fracture is a fracture at metaphyseodiaphyseal junction at the base of 5th metatarsal. Lisfranc fracture is a tarsometatarsal joint injury.

choices.text: Controlled traction of the fracture segment

questions.text: The given below instrument is used for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Holds plate against the bone Serrated margins on one side [ to hold bone] & smooth margins on other [to hold plate].

questions.text: A middle-aged female present with lytic lesion in lower 1/3 of femur. Biopsy showed grooved nuclei and giant cells. No periosteal reaction seen. What is the con?rmatory investigation for this case:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) To confirm on IHC that it is a giant cell tumour. Serum PTH done when suspecting hyperparathyroidism Serum calcitonin done when suspecting calcium disorders or tumour. MRI isn’t confirmatory, already confirmed on BIOPSY

questions.text: A male brought to the casualty after he met with an accident. He was having comminuted fracture in the lower end of femur. His distal pulses were not palpable so a vascular surgeon decided to explore. So the resident did the following procedure given below the picture. What is the name of the ?xator?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rail road fixator creating a rail road network. K-nail is Kuntschner’s nail with clover leaf shaped cross section, intramedullary nail, used for fracture femur & tibia Fixation. Interlocking nail is a modification of K-nail. Ilizarov fixator has semicircular ring frames, olive tip wires, distraction histeogenesis.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) •Madelung deformity has congenital growth retardation of ulnar aspect of distal radial physis leading to abnormally prominent distal ulna. •Haglund deformity: Insertional tendinitis of Tendoachilles/ posterosuperior calcaneal spur formation. •Button hole deformity : Boutonniere deformity of Rheumatoid arthritis. •Gunstock deformity : malunited supracondylar fracture humerus

questions.text: Arrange the options in sequence as part of surgical intervention for DDH: A. Capsulotomy B. Locate the acetabulum by tracing ligament of teres C. Relocated the femoral head in acetabulum D. Derotation femoral osteotomy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Skin incision called Smith-Petersen approach → cut the skin, superficial fascia, deep fascia, rectus Femoris, enter joint – capsule → T-capsulotomy. Open reduction by locating acetabulum by tracing of ligamentum teres. Head is reduced known as relocated Femoral head in acetabulum. Head which is rotated for that do → derotation of Femoral osteotomy.

questions.text: Identify the splint:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dynamic Cockup splint - For radial nerve palsy [wrist drop] Knuckle bender splint for ulnar nerve palsy [CLAW HAND].

questions.text: A boy fell from the height on his outstretched hand. The X-ray is similar to the one shown below. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fracture of shaft of radius at junction of middle and distal ?rd with distal radioulnar joint dislocation – Galeazzi fracture/ Reverse Monteggia’s fracture.

questions.text: A 30-years-old man presents with numbness of both hands. The patient was asked to perform the test demonstrated in the video. What is the test? For video visit link or scan given QR code:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Roos test is performed in cervical rib/thoracic outlet

questions.text: The test performed in the following video is? For video visit link or scan given QR code:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) -Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand , which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation. -Interpretation: As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the color of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5-6 seconds. -If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds , it indicates reduced ulnar collateral blood flow.

questions.text: A 55-years-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a H/o. Intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) History of disc prolapse is evident of Cauda Equina syndrome – happens due to postero-central PIVD. RESPONSIBLE for saddle anaesthesia, sphincter disturbances.

questions.text: What is the treatment modality for the following fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fracture patella, olecranon, greater trochnater, greater tuberosity, Medial malleolus : [Superior pole pulled up by Quadriceps tendon, Inferior pole by ligamentum patellae] - TBW done Tension band wiring converts distraction forces into compressive forces

questions.text: A 55 years-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cubitus varus: supracondylar fracture of humerus – most common complication is MALUNION → GIVES RISE TO Cubitus varus called as GUN STOCK DEFORMITY.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 4-A, 2-B, 3-C, 1-D -The preferred method of Rx of Osteosarcoma is wide resection and reconstruction. -Simple bone cyst usually regresses with bone maturity . In cases where the lesions are active , an injection of steroids is done. - Osteoid Osteoma : The preferred treatment is CT-guided Radiofrequency Ablation. - Giant cell tumor: In stages 1&2 , intralesional curettage with debridement. Stage 3 treated with curettage but some cases requires en-block dissection

questions.text: A pt presented with femur shaft # What all are needed to put tibial skeletal traction ? A. Bohler Braun Splint / Frame B. Bohler stirrup C. Thomas Splint D. Denham’s pin / Durham’s pin E. K wire F. Steinmann’s pin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) F-D-B-A -Steimann pin : The common sites where it is used include the upper end of tibia , supracondylar region of the femur , and the calcaneum . - Bohler 's stirrup: It is used to hold a Steinmann pin and apply traction - Bohler Braun splint : This refers to Bohler's modification of the Braun splint . It is used for the treatment of fracture shaft femur and supracondylar fractures of the femur. Can also be used for fractured shaft of the tibia and fibula.

questions.text: There is nerve injury but nerve sheaths intact. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Axon is injured, nerve sheets are intact : Axontmesis Nothing is injured is neuropraxia

questions.text: A pt with tibial # on cast presents in ER Cast Removed Pain on passive ?exion DP and PTA + Loss of sensation in 1st web space Next Step ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Compartment syndrome Measure the pressure then do Fasciotomy.

questions.text: Arrange the following in terms of stability (Lowest – Highest) A. uniplanar with one rod B. uniplanar with two rods C. Biplanar D. Ilizarov
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-B-C-D External fixation provides rigid fixation of the bones. This is commonly used in severe open type 2& type3 fractures. -The principal of external fixation is the Transfixation of bone above and below the fracture with Schanz screws or tensioned wires and these are connected to each other by a rigid bars. Various types of external fixation devices : - A unilateral frame with a support member and half pins on one plane constitute a unilateral one -plane configuration. The addition of a second support member and the second plane of half pins form a unilateral two-plane configuration. - Transfixation pins connected to support members at either end are used to build the bilateral one-plane configuration. The addition of a second plane of half pins form a bilateral two - plane configuration. - Image of ilizarov fixator is given :

questions.text: 65 years old postmenopausal female came with persistent backache not responding to conservative treatment. History of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100 m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PIVD (Prolapsed Intervertebral Disc) • History of heavy lifting suggests mechanical strain — a classic trigger for disc herniation. • Progressively worsening pain + radiculopathy (leg radiation) within 100 m of walking. • PIVD can cause nerve root compression, leading to: - Back pain - Leg pain - Sometimes symptoms worsen with walking or standing, especially with large or central herniations. • While "relief on climbing stairs" is more typical of lumbar canal stenosis, flexion of the spine during stair climbing can also reduce nerve root tension in some disc herniations. So, this presentation can reasonably be explained by a disc prolapse, especially one that's central or compressing the thecal sac. A. Vertebral Osteoporotic Compression Fracture • Common in postmenopausal women due to osteoporosis. • Often acute or subacute in onset. • Pain is localized to the back, worsens with movement, standing, or sitting, and improves with rest. • No leg radiation typically. • No neurogenic claudication features. • Doesn't explain radiating leg pain or worsening with walking — less likely. C. Lumbar Canal Stenosis • Classic signs: • Neurogenic claudication: Leg pain on walking, relieved by rest or flexion. • Pain relief on stair climbing = supportive of stenosis. • BUT: This is usually a gradual, degenerative condition, not triggered by trauma like heavy lifting. • Typically occurs over years, not 4 months. • No mention of bilateral symptoms, which are more common in stenosis. • Though some signs match (like relief on stair climbing), acute onset after lifting and more focal symptoms favor PIVD instead. D. Isthmic Spondylolisthesis • Caused by a defect in the pars interarticularis, often in younger adults or athletes. • May present with back pain and leg pain. • Not common in elderly females, especially with a traumatic trigger. • Does not classically match the radiating pain after walking 100 m pattern.

questions.text: Timing of first cast application in CTEV?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2 weeks of age Treatment of CTEV should begin as early as first 2 weeks after birth . In CTEV , the deformity is equinus , inversion , forefoot adduction and cavus. - Ponsetti's method is successful method of manipulation in CTEV. The order of correction according to Ponsetti's method is Cavus - Adduction - Varus- Equinus ( CAVE) . Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with the help of plaster casts.

questions.text: A 10 years old child comes with a swelling in the tibial diaphysis, X-ray shows reaction on the surface of the bone, Biopsy of the lesion shows small round cells and MIC2 mutation. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with a mushroom-like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features will help the clinician to identify a malignant transformation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cm The given xray depicts an osteochondroma, or exostosis, which is the most common benign bone tumor. The stalk grows away from the joint line, and the cartilage cap is 2cm B. Heavy calcification C. Persistence of growth after skeletal maturity.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presents with multiple swellings and multiple brown rashes. She has increased uptake on bone scan over femur, skull and ribs. Biochemical parameters are abnormal. She also has a history of hypothyroidism. Following is her xray. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) McCune Albright syndrome The given clinical scenario is that of Fibrous dysplasia which is a developmental anomaly of the bone, where bone tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue+woven bone (immature). McCune Albright syndrome is a triad consisting of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, Café au lait spots and Precocious puberty.

questions.text: A patient came with history of RTA and shaft of femur fracture. Patient was stabilized. After 12 hours, he developed sudden onset breathlessness, confusion and petechial skin rashes over axilla and chest. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fat embolism Fat embolism syndrome usually occurs 48 hours after the fracture. The classical triad seen is Respiratory symptoms like dyspnea or tachypnea, Neurological symptoms like confusion and Petechial rashes.

choices.text: Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis

questions.text: A patient has sustained pelvic fracture in an RTA and is bleeding and in shock. Immediate management of this case should be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tie a bedsheet around the pelvis Pelvic tamponade should be done to prevent the bleeding as it is the most dangerous complication following fracture of the pelvis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man sustained a shoulder injury and presented with swelling of the shoulder. Xray is shown. Which is/are the ligament injured in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament In the given xray, the clavicle is seen displaced upwards. The acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments hold the clavicle in its place. If they are injured, the sternocleidomastoid will exert a one directional upwards force, hence dislocating the clavicle are seen. Hence externally, the clavicle and acromion will no longer be in a straight line, called the “Step sign”.

questions.text: Hawkins classification used in which fracture:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The Hawkins classification is specifically used for fractures of the neck of the talus, a critical bone in the ankle that articulates with the tibia, fibula, calcaneus, and navicular bones. This classification helps in assessing the severity of the fracture and the risk of developing avascular necrosis (AVN) of the talus due to disruption of its delicate blood supply. The classification is divided into four types: Type I refers to a nondisplaced talar neck fracture with minimal risk of AVN; Type II involves a displaced fracture with subluxation or dislocation of the subtalar joint and carries a moderate risk; Type III includes dislocation of both the subtalar and tibiotalar joints, with a high risk of AVN; and Type IV adds dislocation of the talonavicular joint, with nearly 100% risk of AVN. Therefore, among the given options, the correct answer is Talus, as the Hawkins classification is not applicable to navicular, tibia, or calcaneum fractures, which are classified using different systems such as Sangeorzan, AO/OTA, or Sanders respectively.

questions.text: MRI of the knee lateral view, identify the structure marked
questions.solution: Correct Answe-(B)

questions.text: In which of the following fractures does the three point bony relationship is maintained?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which typically occurs just above the elbow joint (in the distal humerus), the three-point bony relationship — formed by the medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, and olecranon when the elbow is flexed at 90° — is generally maintained. This is because the fracture occurs proximal to these bony landmarks, and though the distal fragment may be displaced, the alignment of the epicondyles and olecranon relative to each other remains unchanged. Clinically, this preservation of the triangle helps differentiate supracondylar fractures from dislocations. A. Lateral epicondyle Incorrect. A fracture of the lateral epicondyle may lead to local displacement of the lateral epicondyle, thereby disturbing the bony triangle. Although less severe than dislocation, the three-point relationship may be altered depending on the degree of displacement. B. Medial epicondyle Incorrect. Similar to lateral epicondyle fractures, a medial epicondyle fracture can cause displacement of the medial epicondyle, especially if associated with elbow instability or dislocation, thus disrupting the normal triangle. D. Elbow dislocation Incorrect. In an elbow dislocation, particularly posterior dislocation, the olecranon shifts posteriorly, which leads to a clear disruption of the three-point bony relationship. This is a key clinical sign that helps distinguish dislocation from fractures where the triangle is preserved.

choices.text: Injury to anterior inferior glenoid labrum
Injury of anterior superior glenoid labrum
Depression in posteroinferior head of humerus
Depression in the posterosuperior part of head of humerus

questions.text: True statement about Bankarts lesion in recurrent anterior dislocation of shoulder:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Injury to anterior inferior glenoid labrum A Bankart lesion specifically refers to a tear or avulsion of the anterior inferior portion of the glenoid labrum. This injury occurs when the humeral head dislocates anteriorly, often in a traumatic event or recurrent dislocations, leading to detachment of the labrum from the glenoid rim. This disruption compromises the stability of the shoulder joint by impairing the function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament complex, which is crucial for maintaining the congruence of the joint. The precise involvement of the anterior inferior labrum is what defines the Bankart lesion and distinguishes it from other shoulder injuries. Incorrect Options: Option B – Injury of anterior superior glenoid labrum This option is incorrect because the injury in a Bankart lesion is not located at the anterior superior labrum. Injuries to the superior labrum are typically associated with SLAP (Superior Labrum Anterior and Posterior) lesions, which have a different mechanism and clinical presentation compared to Bankart lesions. Option C – Depression in posteroinferior head of humerus This option is not correct. The depression described here does not correspond with a Bankart lesion. Instead, Hill-Sachs lesions—impaction fractures caused by the humeral head impacting against the glenoid rim during dislocation—are usually found on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head, not posteroinferior. Option D – Depression in the posterosuperior part of head of humerus This statement is also incorrect because it misidentifies the location and nature of the typical osseous defect associated with shoulder dislocations. A Bankart lesion involves soft tissue damage at the glenoid rim, specifically the anterior inferior part, rather than a depression in any part of the humeral head. The location given in this option does not relate to any classic findings in anterior shoulder instability.

questions.text: C/o symmetric arthritis, involving multiple joints like wrist, hands, feet, bilateral nature.. morning stiffness present. Swollen and tender joints seen-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) The patient's presentation is most consistent with Rheumatoid Arthritis. RA is characterized by a symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints such as the wrists, hands, and feet. Patients frequently report morning stiffness that lasts for more than 30 minutes, and clinical examination typically reveals swollen and tender joints. These key features—symmetry, multiple joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and observable joint inflammation—strongly support the diagnosis of RA. Incorrect Options: Option B – Psoriatic Arthritis Although psoriatic arthritis can involve the small joints of the hands and feet, it usually presents with an asymmetric pattern and is associated with skin psoriasis. The symmetric nature of the arthritis described, along with the prominent morning stiffness and multiple joint swelling, does not align with the typical features of psoriatic arthritis. Option C – Osteoarthritis Osteoarthritis generally manifests as a non-inflammatory joint disease characterized by joint pain and stiffness that typically worsens with activity rather than with prolonged morning stiffness. Additionally, osteoarthritis is commonly asymmetrical and primarily affects weight-bearing joints, which contrasts with the symmetric, inflammatory pattern described in the question. Option D – Ankylosing Spondylitis Ankylosing Spondylitis predominantly affects the axial skeleton, particularly the sacroiliac joints and spine, and is less likely to present as a symmetric polyarthritis involving the small joints of the wrists, hands, and feet. The features of pronounced morning stiffness and peripheral joint swelling are not typical for Ankylosing Spondylitis.

questions.text: Fracture at the marked site will produce which type of gait abnormality?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The image shows a fracture at the fibular neck, which is the common site of injury to the common peroneal nerve. Injury to this nerve causes: Foot drop (due to loss of dorsiflexion) Loss of eversion (due to involvement of superficial peroneal nerve) To compensate for foot drop, patients lift their knee higher while walking → resulting in a steppage gait. Incorrect Options: B. Waddling gait Seen in bilateral proximal muscle weakness, e.g., Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Due to weakness of hip abductors, not associated with fibular fractures. C. Antalgic gait A pain-avoidance gait, where the stance phase is shortened on the painful side. Typically seen in painful conditions, not primarily due to nerve injury. D. Widened gait Seen in cerebellar ataxia or balance disorders. Characterized by a broad base for stability, unrelated to peroneal nerve injury.

questions.text: Following are the intrinsic muscle associated with foot
questions.solution: Correct Answe-(B)

choices.text: Most common bone fracture in wrist is lunate
Most common bone fracture is scaphoid in wrist
Glass holding cast for fracture Scaphoid

questions.text: Mark the false statement out of the following statement
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Most common bone fracture in wrist is lunate — False The lunate bone is rarely fractured. The most common wrist bone fracture is actually the scaphoid bone. B. Most common bone fracture is scaphoid in wrist — True Scaphoid fractures are the most frequent fractures of the carpal bones in the wrist. C. Glass holding cast for fracture Scaphoid — True The “glass holding” or “thumb spica” cast is the classical immobilization used for scaphoid fractures. D. Osteonecrosis happens in navicular bone — True The navicular bone (another name for the scaphoid) is prone to osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) due to its peculiar blood supply.

questions.text: Positive Trendelenberggait indicates involvement of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A. Gluteus medius Function: Main hip abductor, stabilizes the pelvis during walking. Relation: Its weakness causes Trendelenburg gait. Involved, but muscle weakness is usually secondary to nerve damage. Not the best answer, because the nerve is the root cause. B. Sciatic nerve Function: Innervates posterior thigh muscles, hamstrings, and all muscles below the knee (motor), plus sensory to the lower leg and foot. Relation: Does not innervate gluteus medius/minimus. Not involved in Trendelenburg gait. C. Gluteus minimus Function: Assists gluteus medius in hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Involved, but plays a supporting role. Again, the muscle is not the primary cause — the nerve is. D. Superior Gluteal Nerve Function: Innervates gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae. Relation: Injury to this nerve causes weakness in hip abductors, leading to Trendelenburg gait. Correct answer — this is the root cause when the sign is positive.
